item.description: Nvidia stock was dropping early on Tuesday, hit both by wider market jitters over President Donald Trump’s drive to acquire Greenland and doubts about where the artificial-intelligence boom goes from here. Nvidia shares were down 2.9% at $180.84 in early trading Tuesday, while the has fallen 1.1%, and the has declined 1%. The move was broadly line with the wider market: Technology stocks are out of favor as investors flee to haven assets such as gold.

item.title: [GOOG] AI startup Humans& raises $480 million at $4.5 billion valuation in seed round
item.description: AI startup Humans&, founded by former OpenAI, Alphabet and xAI researchers, has raised $480 million ​in a seed financing round, which values the company ‌at $4.48 billion, it said on Tuesday. The outsized seed round highlights intense investor interest ‌in next-generation AI labs founded by veteran researchers as companies race to build systems that go beyond chatbots and agentic tools. The round was led by Ron Conway's SV Angel and co-founder Georges Harik, ⁠while Nvidia, Jeff Bezos, ‌Alphabet's VC arm, GV, among other venture capital investors, also participated.

item.title: [NVDA] Netflix Results to Shine Light on Fundamentals Amid Warner Fight
item.description: Investors have been concerned about Netflix’s slowing flow of subscribers and the sustainability of its growth. The issue sparked the worst selloff in the stock in more than three years after the company’s previous earnings report on Oct. 21. At the time, Netflix was seen as a possible suitor for Warner Bros. Now that the deal is on the table at $82.7 billion, some investors are on edge and all the risks are amplified.

item.title: [NVDA] Tech Weekly: Grok in hot water, app checks if you're dead or alive
item.description:
STORY: From Grok getting xAI in trouble to a Chinese app that checks if you're dead or alive, this is Tech Weekly.

:: Tech Weekly

Elon Musk's xAI imposed image editing restrictions on all users of its Grok AI chatbot.

It happened after concerns grew when the service produced sexualized images.

Governments and regulators from Europe and Asia had cracked down on sexually explicit content made by Grok.

xAI said it implemented measures to stop Grok from allowing the editing of images of real people in revealing clothing.

///

U.S President Donald Trump imposed a 25% tariff on certain AI chips under a new national security order.

Products affected include Nvidia's H200 and a rival semiconductor from AMD.

The Trump administration argued the U.S. is too reliant on foreign supply chains which it called a national security risk.

The move targets a number of high-end semiconductors meeting certain performance benchmarks and devices containing them.

///

TSMC profits jumped 35% in the fourth-quarter to $16 billion.

The Taiwanese chip giant scored big from the AI boom and predicted more strong growth this year.

It further said it was working on building fresh U.S. manufacturing capacity.

TSMC - which counts Apple and Nvidia as major customers - announced plans last year to invest $100 billion in the U.S.

////

TikTok will roll out new age-detection technology across Europe in the coming weeks.

The system analyses profile information, posted videos and behavioural signals to predict whether an account may be underage.

TikTok said flagged accounts will be reviewed by specialist moderators rather than automatically banned.

The rollout comes as European authorities look into how platforms verify users' ages under strict data-protection rules.

////

And a new app has gone viral in China which checks if users are still alive.

The app called Sileme in Chinese translates as 'Are you dead?'

It's aimed at people living alone or who live a solitary lifestyle.

It sends automatic notifications to an emergency contact if the user hasn't checked in for consecutive days.

Downloads have surged, leading the firm to introduce a subscription fee and change its name for a global audience.

item.title: [NVDA] Taiwan's Inventec says decision on Nvidia's H200 chip 'appears to be stuck' on China's side
item.description: Taiwanese server maker Inventec said on Tuesday that a decision on whether Nvidia will ​be able to sell its H200 artificial intelligence chip in ‌China "appears to be stuck on the China side". The U.S. formally approved the chip for export ‌to China last week with some conditions. Reuters reported last week that Chinese customs authorities told customs agents that the H200 chip was not permitted to enter China though it was not clear whether this constituted ⁠a formal ban or ‌a temporary measure.

item.title: [NVDA] Surrounded by billionaires in Davos, Trump plans to lay out how he'll make housing more affordable
item.description: President Donald Trump plans to use a key address Wednesday to try to convince Americans he can make housing more affordable, but he's picked a strange backdrop for the speech: a Swiss mountain town where ski chalets for vacations cost a cool $4.4 million. On the anniversary of his inauguration, Trump is flying to the World Economic Forum in Davos — an annual gathering of the global elite — where he may see many of the billionaires he has surrounded himself with during his first year back in the White House. Trump had campaigned on lowering the cost of living, painting himself as a populist while serving fries at a McDonald's drive-thru.
